overview.title: What is Frenzel?
overview.content: Frenzel Equalizing is a technique where you close the glottis and push air to the middle ear using the tongue. It is primarily used for deep diving in head-first position.

principle.title: Principle of Frenzel
principle.content: Frenzel works through the coordination of three main muscles
principle.glottis: Glottis: Closes the airway to the lungs to prevent air from escaping, while maintaining a relaxed state without tension in the neck.
principle.softPalate: Soft Palate: Keeps the airway to the nose open so air can be delivered to the middle ear (Eustachian tube).
principle.tongue: Tongue: Acts as a piston, pushing air upward through the mouth to deliver it to the middle ear via the Eustachian tube.

day1.title: Understanding Glottis
day1.goal: Recognize the sensation of closing the glottis clearly.
day1.step1: Take a deep breath through your mouth and hold it.
day1.step2: Feel the sensation of your throat locking.
day1.step3: Touch your neck with your hand to ensure it doesn't expand.
day1.step4: Try to exhale through your nose while holding your breath. (Success if no air moves)
day1.step5: Make an "ahh" sound while alternating between opening/closing 10 times.
day1.success: Breath is held, neck is relaxed, and no air sound.

day2.title: Advanced Glottis Control
day2.goal: Consciously control opening and closing of the glottis.
day2.step1: Breathe in through your mouth and close the glottis.
day2.step2: Hold for 5 seconds then open with "ahh".
day2.step3: Practice alternating closed ↔ open to learn the difference.
day2.step4: Ensure only the glottis works without neck tension.
day2.success: Breath stops with a quiet neck, air flows smoothly when opened.

day3.title: Understanding Soft Palate
day3.goal: Distinguish between opening and closing of the nasal passage (soft palate).
day3.step2: Breathe only through your mouth → closed.
day3.step3: Make an "ng" sound and check if you feel nasal vibration.
day3.step4: If vibration disappears when nose is blocked with "ng" sound, it's closed.
day3.success: Feel the passage behind the nose 'opening' when open.

day4.title: Advanced Soft Palate Control
day4.goal: Freely switch between opening and closing the soft palate.
day4.step2: Mimic yawning and learn the sensation of widening the nasal passage.
day4.step3: Recognize that nasal vibration means open, no vibration means closed.
day4.success: Clear and free transition between opening and closing of nasal passage.

day5.title: Basic K/T Tongue Movement
day5.goal: Learn tongue position and air pushing motion.
day5.step1: Close glottis and close your mouth.
day5.step2: Press and release the back of tongue (K position) against the palate.
day5.step3: Lightly push with the front of tongue (T position) and feel the difference.
day5.success: Slight pressure sensation in ears or back of nose, quiet neck.

day6.title: Tongue Piston Pressure Control
day6.goal: Control air pressure consistently with tongue movement.
day6.step1: Close glottis + keep soft palate open.
day6.step2: Push air with K tongue motion.
day6.step4: Check for uniform pressure and rhythm.
day6.success: Consistent 'pop pop' pressure in ears, steady airflow.

day7.title: Sensory Integration Stage 1
day7.goal: Perform glottis closure + soft palate opening + tongue piston simultaneously.
day7.step2: Open soft palate with a yawning sensation.
day7.step4: Success when pressure is felt in ears.
day7.step5: In final step, lightly pinch nose and repeat same motion to learn actual pressure transfer sensation.
day7.success: Slight 'pop' sensation in ears without neck movement.

day8.title: Sensory Integration Stage 2 (Rhythm)
day8.step1: Keep glottis closed + soft palate open.
day8.step3: Maintain steady rhythm and uniform pressure.
day8.step4: From last 5 reps, train rhythm maintenance with nose pinched.
day8.step5: Maintain consistent 'pop pop' sensation in ears.
day8.success: Steady rhythm, uniform ear pressure, no neck tension.

day9.title: Head-first Frenzel Adaptation Stage 1
day9.goal: Maintain soft palate in head-down position.
day9.step1: Sit in chair and tilt head down 45°.
day9.step2: Close glottis + keep soft palate open.
day9.step5: Perform all steps with nose pinched to learn pressure sensation similar to actual underwater environment.
day9.success: Nasal passage stays open and ear pressure transfers even with head down.

day10.title: Head-first Frenzel Completion
day10.goal: Stable Frenzel performance even at full head-down position (90°).
day10.step1: Fully tilt head down (90°) and close glottis.
day10.step2: Perform soft palate opening + tongue K motion.
day10.step3: Train with nose pinched from the start.
day10.success: Even with head down: relaxed neck, nasal passage open, inner ear equilibrium maintained.

completed.title: Training Completed!
completed.message: You have completed the CO₂ table training.

notifications.greatJob: Great job! You completed Day {{dayNumber}} Frenzel training.
